TextEquiv.Unicode: to our copany. Moreover in our coun
trey speech wee will call our neigh
bour, Der abenmensch, namlich ein
yeder der so wol ein mensch ist als
wir: meaning thereby any man what
soever whether hee be our friende or
enemie. Hereunto belongeth that say
ing of Lactantius in the eleventh
chapter of his sirt booke. why ma
kest thou thoyce of personss why loo
kest thou so narrowly on the limmess
Thou must take him to bee a man,
whosoever beseecheth thee, therefore
that he may thinke thee to be a man,
Give to the blinde, to the impotent,
to the lame, to the comfortlesse, to
whome unlesse thou be liberall, thou
shalt die undoubtedlie. Againe hee
saith: If so be we will rightly be called
by the name of men, then must we in
any case keepe the lawe of civill hu
manitie. And what else I pray you is
it to keepe humanitie but therefore to
love a man because hee is a man, and
the verie same that wee our selves are,
The Lord in the Gospell verily speak
ing of the love of our neighbour saith:
Love your enemies, blesse them that
curse you, doe good to them that hate
you, pray for them that hurt you. And
againe, Give to every one that at keth
of thee. And if you love them that love
you, what thanke is that to yourFor sin
ners alsolove the of whom they are lo
ved. So then every man who so ever
standeth in neede of our ayde, both is,
and is to be counted our neighbour,
And yet all this notwithstanding
there is no cause but that there ought
to be, an order, a measure and decent
regarde in love and well doing. For
rightly sayde saint Augustine in the,
23. Chapter of his booke De dostrins
Cbristiana: No sinner in that hee is a
sinner is to bee loved. And in the 26.
Chapter: All men are to bee loved

to our copany. Moreover in our coun trey speech wee will call our neigh bour, Der abenmensch, namlich ein yeder der so wol ein mensch ist als wir: meaning thereby any man what soever whether hee be our friende or enemie. Hereunto belongeth that say ing of Lactantius in the eleventh chapter of his sirt booke. why ma kest thou thoyce of personss why loo kest thou so narrowly on the limmess Thou must take him to bee a man, whosoever beseecheth thee, therefore that he may thinke thee to be a man, Give to the blinde, to the impotent, to the lame, to the comfortlesse, to whome unlesse thou be liberall, thou shalt die undoubtedlie. Againe hee saith: If so be we will rightly be called by the name of men, then must we in any case keepe the lawe of civill hu manitie. And what else I pray you is it to keepe humanitie but therefore to love a man because hee is a man, and the verie same that wee our selves are, The Lord in the Gospell verily speak ing of the love of our neighbour saith: Love your enemies, blesse them that curse you, doe good to them that hate you, pray for them that hurt you. And againe, Give to every one that at keth of thee. And if you love them that love you, what thanke is that to yourFor sin ners alsolove the of whom they are lo ved. So then every man who so ever standeth in neede of our ayde, both is, and is to be counted our neighbour, And yet all this notwithstanding there is no cause but that there ought to be, an order, a measure and decent
regarde in love and well doing. For rightly sayde saint Augustine in the, 23. Chapter of his booke De dostrins Cbristiana: No sinner in that hee is a sinner is to bee loved. And in the 26. Chapter: All men are to bee loved
alike, but since thou canst not do good
to all men, therefore thou must etpeci
ally doe good to them, to whom thou
art as it were by lot more neerely ioy
ned by opportunitie eyther of time,
of place, or of anie other thing what
soever. And this did Paul before Au
gustine teach, where he saith: who
soever worketh not, let him not cate,
And againe, while wee have time let
us worke good to all men, but speci
ally to them of the housholde of faith,
And in an other place he commandeth
us not to bestowe on others, & to lacke
our selves at home. But rather he
charegeth everie one to have a godly
care of his owne house. The place is
knowen in the fift Chapter of the first
Epistle to Timothie.
Nowe since I have declared who
is our neighbor, let us see also in what
fort this neighbour of ours ought to
be loved. Our neighbour must be lo
ved simplie without any coloured de
ceipt, with the verie felfe same love
wherwith we love our selves, or that
wherewith Christ hath loved us. For
in al things we must stand our neigh
bour in sleede, & do himpleasure so far
as ye law of humanitie shalbe found to
require. In this declaration ther are
foure thinges more fully to be noted.
First that love of our neighbour
that is looked for at our handes ought
to be so sincere as that it bee without
all manner guile, deceipt and coloured
craft. For there are many to be found,
that have the skill to talke to their
neighbours with sugred tongues, and
to make a facer as though they loved)
them, when as in deede they doe utter
ly hate them, meaning nothing else
but with fauning wordes to beguile
them, that thereby they may worke
the thinges that they desire. Paule
and John therefore, the Apostles of

alike, but since thou canst not do good to all men, therefore thou must etpeci ally doe good to them, to whom thou art as it were by lot more neerely ioy ned by opportunitie eyther of time, of place, or of anie other thing what soever. And this did Paul before Au gustine teach, where he saith: who soever worketh not, let him not cate, And againe, while wee have time let us worke good to all men, but speci ally to them of the housholde of faith, And in an other place he commandeth us not to bestowe on others, & to lacke our selves at home. But rather he charegeth everie one to have a godly care of his owne house. The place is knowen in the fift Chapter of the first Epistle to Timothie. Nowe since I have declared who is our neighbor, let us see also in what fort this neighbour of ours ought to be loved. Our neighbour must be lo ved simplie without any coloured de ceipt, with the verie felfe same love wherwith we love our selves, or that wherewith Christ hath loved us. For in al things we must stand our neigh bour in sleede, & do himpleasure so far as ye law of humanitie shalbe found to require. In this declaration ther are foure thinges more fully to be noted. First that love of our neighbour that is looked for at our handes ought to be so sincere as that it bee without all manner guile, deceipt and coloured craft. For there are many to be found, that have the skill to talke to their neighbours with sugred tongues, and to make a facer as though they loved) them, when as in deede they doe utter ly hate them, meaning nothing else but with fauning wordes to beguile them, that thereby they may worke the thinges that they desire.
